key_title: Key to the genera of Restionaceae
notes: Key modified to include former Centrolepidaceae, Val Stajsic, 17 July 2019.

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Restionaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Conn, B.J. (1994). Restionaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves well developed, or if ever reduced to sheathing bracts then these fused at the base and plants with both male and female flowers or flowers bisexual
Wiry plants with jointed stems; leaves reduced to sheathing bracts (bracts overlapping at base); male and female plants separate (except sometimes in Lepyrodia)
Inflorescence laterally flattened and spike-like; primary bracts 5–12; flowers distinct, not clustered
Inflorescence head-like; primary bracts 2, more or less enclosing the inflorescence with their basal sheaths; flowers clustered into bisexual and female units
Flowers in a narrow, branched inflorescence, not grouped in spikelets (not arranged alternately above 2 empty floral bracts); plants dioecious or monoecious or with bisexual flowers
Male flowers in spikelets; female flowers usually in spikelets; plants dioecious (in Victoria)
Green tissue of stems forming a continuous cylinder, not interrupted; stems usually not striate; glabrous or hairy, but never with a dense covering of broad multi-cellular hairs

Green tissue of stems interrupted by lines of enlarged epidermal cells or by pillar cells (lacking chloroplasts); stems striate, at least when dry; glabrous or hairy, sometimes with a greyish covering of closely appressed broad multi-cellular hairs

Ovary 2-chambered; style branches 2; male spikelets arranged in large branching clusters or if in compact clusters then total inflorescence (1.5–) 2–6 cm long and subtending floral bracts 10–30 mm long, 3–6 mm wide
Ovary 1-chambered; style branches 1–3; male spikelets arranged in small, compact clusters less than 1 cm long and subtending floral bracts 3–7 mm long, up to c. 3 mm wide
Sheathing bracts very deciduous, leaving distinct dark annular scars; stems mostly unbranched; male spikelets with more than 20 flowers
Sheathing bracts persistent; stems branched or unbranched; male spikelets with fewer than 20 flowers
[link through]
Rhizome not hairy; perianth firm, brown; female flowers with 3 staminodes; male spikelets 1-flowered
Rhizome hairy; perianth membranous, pale; female flowers without staminodes; male spikelets 2–several-flowered
[link through]
[link through]
Ovary 2-chambered; anthers exserted on long, slender filaments; stems flattened
Ovary 1-chambered; anthers almost sessile and included, or on short filaments and just exserted; stems subterete or terete
[link through]
Female inflorescence made up of 1-flowered clusters; each flower subtended by a floral bract; male plants unbranched, with 1 or 2 branches, or branched at the base only
Female inflorescence made up of 1-flowered, sessile spikelets; each flower surrounded by 3–6 sterile floral bracts; male plants much-branched
[link through]
Male and female inflorescences very different in appearance; male spikelets 3–5 mm long; female spikelets simple, 1–many flowered
Male and female inflorescences nearly similar; male spikelets 5–15 mm long; female flowers arranged in dense, crowded clusters, spikelets indistinct, 3–5 flowered
[link through]
[link through]

Erect or scrambling monoecious or dioecious herbs; stem ± smooth; hollow portion of stem pith circular in section; perianth whorls ± equal in length, outer sometimes longer than inner, or plants monoecious if inner is longer
Scrambling dioecious herbs; stems minutely warty; hollow portion of stem pith triangular in section or indistinct; male flowers with inner perianth much longer than the outer
[link through]
